title: Ube-Macapuno Cake Recipe
description: Filipino ube cake is made with purple yams, filled with macapuno (coconut preserves), and frosted with sweet buttercream for a gorgeous 3-layer cake.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines Asian Filipino Ube-Macapuno Cake 3.8 (51) 42 Reviews 23 Photos Ube cake is a deliciously light Filipino cake made with purple yams and macapuno (coconut sport). Its vibrant purple color will look gorgeous on any dessert table! Submitted by Jackie Updated on September 8, 2022 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 23 23 23 23 Prep Time: 30 mins Cook Time: 30 mins Total Time: 1 hr Servings: 12 Yield: 1 3-layer 9-inch cake Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 12 servings Ube Cake: 2 ½ cups cake flour 3 teaspoons baking powder 1 teaspoon salt 1 cup ube (purple yam), cooked and finely grated ¾ cup milk 1 teaspoon vanilla extract 7 egg yolks, lightly beaten ½ cup corn syrup ½ cup vegetable oil 7 egg whites 1 teaspoon cream of tartar 1 cup white sugar 6 drops red food color 6 drops blue food coloring 1 (12 ounce) jar macapuno (coconut preserves) Buttercream: 1 cup evaporated milk, chilled ¾ cup white sugar 1 cup butter, softened 1 drop violet food coloring Directions Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Line the bottom of three 9-inch round pans with parchment paper, but do not grease. Make the ube cake: Mix flour, baking powder, and salt together in a large bowl; set aside. Place grated ube in a large bowl. Combine 3/4 cup milk and 1 teaspoon vanilla; gradually blend into ube until smooth. Blend in egg yolks, corn syrup, and oil. Beat in flour mixture until smooth; set aside. Combine egg whites and cream of tartar in a large bowl; beat with an electric mixer until foamy. Gradually add sugar, then red and blue food coloring, continuing to beat until stiff peaks form. Fold 1/3 of the whites into batter, then quickly fold in remaining whites until no streaks remain. Pour batter into prepared pans. Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean, about 30 to 35 minutes. Invert pans on a wire rack and let cool upside down. When cool, run a knife around the edges to loosen cake from the pans. Spread coconut preserves onto the cooled cake layers; stack layers on a cake stand or serving plate. Make the buttercream: Combine evaporated milk and 3/4 cup sugar; set aside. Combine butter and sugar in a large bowl; beat with an electric mixer until smooth and creamy. Beat in food coloring, one drop at a time, until the desired tint is achieved. Frost top and sides of cake with buttercream. I Made It Print 68 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 714 Calories 44g Fat 75g Carbs 12g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 12 Calories 714 % Daily Value * Total Fat 44g 56% Saturated Fat 13g 67% Cholesterol 168mg 56% Sodium 469mg 20% Total Carbohydrate 75g 27% Dietary Fiber 1g 3% Total Sugars 36g Protein 12g 24% Vitamin C 0mg 0% Calcium 232mg 18% Iron 4mg 19% Potassium 266mg 6% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. Add Your Photo Photos of Ube-Macapuno Cake 01 of 23 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 23 Photo by  HardyPeel1935 05/01/2022 03 of 23 Photo by  Cherry Dasmarinas Marcia 04/06/2019 Cake was good, but l added more ube halaya (ube in jar). Frosting didn't do well. Did my own butter frosting. 04 of 23 Photo by  hanan 03/19/2018 I've always loved ube cake...and I'm so glad I found a good recipe that works! some of the reviews I read had me hesitating but I'm glad I followed through. I improvised and discarded an ingredient (corn syrup) since I didn't have one, i also beat the sugar with the egg yolks instead. I halved the recipe just to see if it would turn out well. I made a runny liquidy type of frosting (if you would call it that) that used whipped condensed milk with butter, something I learned from a nearby pinoy restaurant that does so. Definitely recommend to try this recipe. 05 of 23 Photo by  hanan 03/19/2018 I've always loved ube cake...and I'm so glad I found a good recipe that works! some of the reviews I read had me hesitating but I'm glad I followed through. I improvised and discarded an ingredient (corn syrup) since I didn't have one, i also beat the sugar with the egg yolks instead. I halved the recipe just to see if it would turn out well. I made a runny liquidy type of frosting (if you would call it that) that used whipped condensed milk with butter, something I learned from a nearby pinoy restaurant that does so. Definitely recommend to try this recipe. 06 of 23 Photo by  Craig Merchant 09/06/2017 Good tasting, nice dense cake structure. I couldn't find coconut preserves so I used a coconut cream that I made for in between layers. Also, I used half crisco and vegtable oil because in the past I found the all veg oil cakes to be dry. The flour mixture turns a little gray until you add the food coloring though I couldn't quite get the bright purple back. I left the frosting white for better presentaion contrast and added a cheddar cheese garnish (after doing some research). All in all, a nice cake! 07 of 23 Photo by  leah_martz 06/20/2016 08 of 23 Photo by  choy4baby 11/06/2015 09 of 23 Photo by  Jobie Queen 01/03/2015 Always a hit! Can be an acquired taste to some. I follow the exact recipe but made them as cupcakes! 10 of 23 Photo by  Jobie Queen 01/03/2015 Always a hit! Can be an acquired taste to some. I follow the exact recipe but made them as cupcakes! 1 2 3 Next You’ll Also Love Purple Yam and Coconut Mochi (Ube Bibingka) 1 Rating Ube Halaya Ube Cheesecake 13 Ratings Easy and Delicious Purple Yam (Ube) Cookies 7 Ratings Ube Panna Cotta 10 Ratings Cassava Cake 56 Ratings Mamon (Sponge Cakes) 31 Ratings Mocha Chiffon Cake 5 Ratings Golden Yam Brownies 497 Ratings Gluten-Free Golden Yam Brownies 2 Ratings Aargau Carrot Cake 43 Ratings Maraschino Cherry Nut Cake 15 Ratings Ukrainian Prune Torte 5 Ratings Candied Yam Cupcakes 13 Ratings Blackberry Jam Cake III 13 Ratings Almond Rhubarb Coffee Cake 204 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: Jackie
instructions: Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Line the bottom of three 9-inch round pans with parchment paper, but do not grease.;Make the ube cake: Mix flour, baking powder, and salt together in a large bowl; set aside. Place grated ube in a large bowl. Combine 3/4 cup milk and 1 teaspoon vanilla; gradually blend into ube until smooth. Blend in egg yolks, corn syrup, and oil. Beat in flour mixture until smooth; set aside.;Combine egg whites and cream of tartar in a large bowl; beat with an electric mixer until foamy. Gradually add sugar, then red and blue food coloring, continuing to beat until stiff peaks form. Fold 1/3 of the whites into batter, then quickly fold in remaining whites until no streaks remain. Pour batter into prepared pans.;Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean, about 30 to 35 minutes. Invert pans on a wire rack and let cool upside down. When cool, run a knife around the edges to loosen cake from the pans. Spread coconut preserves onto the cooled cake layers; stack layers on a cake stand or serving plate.;Make the buttercream: Combine evaporated milk and 3/4 cup sugar; set aside. Combine butter and sugar in a large bowl; beat with an electric mixer until smooth and creamy. Beat in food coloring, one drop at a time, until the desired tint is achieved. Frost top and sides of cake with buttercream.
